title: Koala population risks starvation following baby boom at Mount Lofty Ranges, study finds | ABC NEWS
description: A new study has found the koala population living in Adelaide's Mount Lofty Ranges is at an unsustainable level and could lead to starvation and death.  Researchers suggest 22 per cent of female koalas in the area to be sterilised annually to stabilise the population.  The population management program is estimated to cost $34 million over the next 25 years but the SA environment minister said she could not commit to the funding. description: Spain is reeling after its worst rail disaster in more than a decade. Dozens have died in the country's south after two high-speed trains collided. Lily Mayers joined The World's Manny Tsigas from Madrid for the latest updates. title: Samurai exhibition breathes new life into ancient tradition | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Samurai warriors are an iconic part of Japan's history and for years have been a source of inspiration for films, video games and comics. As Rebecca Johnston reports, there are now fears the tradition could be fading from the public consciousness, prompting one martial arts expert to revive the practice for modern audiences. title: UK PM calls for calm amid Greenland takeover fears | The World | ABC NEWS
description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has called for "calm discussion" and "fairness" as the United States threatens further tariffs against its European allies as part of its push to acquire Greenland. Professor David Dunn from the University of Birmingham tells Manny Tsigas from "The World" Prime Minister Starmer's words were measured, but firm. title: Tennis stars push for better pay and conditions | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Representatives of the world's top tennis stars have been meeting with officials at the Australian Open to demand a bigger share of the tournament's revenue. The Professional Tennis Players' Association is seeking increased prize money and greater consultation over tournament scheduling, as well as more commercial freedom. Just days into this year's extravaganza, the Australian Open is already boasting record crowds and a substantial increase in its prize money. Tom Larner from Tennis Australia tells The World it wants to see players "remunerated appropriately". title: Sydney's third shark attack in two days triggers sweeping beach closures | ABC NEWS
description: A man in his 20s has sustained serious leg injuries in Sydney’s third shark attack in just over 24 hours, as an unprecedented spate of shark encounters prompts sweeping beach closures.  Hours earlier, a 12-year-old boy suffered life-threatening injuries after a shark bit him in Vaucluse and an 11-year-old’s surfboard was damaged in a shark attack in Dee Why.  The 12-year-old boy remains in a critical condition at the Sydney Children’s Hospital in Randwick. Experts say recent heavy rainfall and murky water conditions triggered the wave of shark attacks. title: Can Europe stop Trump from taking Greenland? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Greenland is one of Donald Trump’s biggest obsessions right now.   If you don’t like his dream of the US taking over the self-governed island, which is part of Denmark, then you’ll be punished.    The president is now slapping tariffs on European nations pushing back against the idea.      Today, the ABC’s global affairs editor Laura Tingle on how the UK and Europe will respond and what it means for the future of NATO.     Featured:    Laura Tingle, ABC global affairs editor

title: Trump text reveals link between Greenland takeover bid and Nobel Peace Prize snub | ABC NEWS
description: A leaked text message from US President Donald Trump has revealed a connection between his failure to land the Nobel Peace Prize and his ambition to acquire Greenland.  The US president told Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre he no longer thinks 'purely of peace' after the Nobel Committee's decision not to give him the award for his so-called peace efforts. Donald Trump also questioned Denmark’s claim to Greenland and the Copenhagen’s ability to defend the Arctic territory from Russian and Chinese threats. title: What we know about Spain's deadly train collision | ABC NEWS
description: Emergency workers are working around the clock to scour the carriages of two derailed trains which collided between Malaga and Madrid in Spain.  The crash near Adamuz is considered the country’s deadliest transport disaster in a decade, as the death toll rose to at least 40 people.  Spanish Transport Minister Óscar Puente Santiago has called the accident 'very strange’ and highlighted the crash happened in a recently renovated part of the network which was designed for automation, while the country’s Union of Railway Drivers (SEMAF) had been urging authorities to examine the conditions of these tracks for years.  Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez has declared three days of national mourning in the wake of the disaster. title: Australian company battles illegal trade to crack Chinese seahorse market | ABC NEWS
description: Now a staple of school holiday trips, Tasmania's Seahorse World originally set out to harvest, dry, and export vast numbers of the creatures for the traditional Chinese medicine market, with the aim of conserving wild populations.   But the unregulated trade of illegally harvested seahorses has kept the Beauty Point business locked out of the market. title: Online retailers like Amazon have changed customers' delivery expectations | ABC NEWS
description: Next-day and same-day delivery for packages used to cost Australians a premium, but e-commerce giants like Amazon have changed customer expectations. New research shows more than half of young Australians expect all businesses to deliver just as quickly, and it has smaller retailers scrambling to keep up.
